comments.body:
The naming is really confusing here. I.e., 'ledger configuration' means two different (though related) concepts: `LedgerConfiguration` describes how we _initialize_ the ledger configuration, `Configuration` describes the _actual configuration parameters_ for e.g. the time model, while `CurrentLedgerConfiguration` provides the latest ledger configuration (a `Configuration` instance, not a `LedgerConfiguration` instance).

Can we clean up this naming, please? Here are a few suggestions:
* `CurrentLedgerConfiguration` => `LedgerConfigurationProvider` or `CurrentLedgerConfigurationProvider` (this would allow moving the `owner` logic here to where the interface is being defined).
* `LedgerConfiguration` =>  `LedgerConfigInitializationParameters` or simply `com.daml.ledger.configuration.InitializationParameters`

I plan on renaming `LedgerConfiguration` as part of subsequent work.

I'm not sure what the issue is with `CurrentLedgerConfiguration`. And I don't understand why you're suggesting to couple the interface to the implementation; my intent was to keep them separate.
Sounds good. My main issue with `CurrentLedgerConfiguration` is the confusing name, I agree with keeping the implementation separate from the interface definition.
